comments.body:
These ideas are not very good in my opinion, not only because Minecraft is not a role-playing game, but also because you seem not to have really thought about how these changes might affect the rest of the game. For example, being able to play as a small character probably would mean you could fit through one-block high ceilings and have a smaller hitbox, which could give you an unfair advantage over other players in multiplayer or PVP settings. And tell me, how exactly would adding crawling or laying down enrich or add to the game? If your only answer is "storytelling", then you need to reconsider the soundness of your ideas.

That said, I would definitely encourage you to look into modded Minecraft (if you don't know, that basically means add-ons that someone else created for the game). Someone more knowledgeable than me might be able to point you to specifics, but I am sure that you could find mods that add some of the features you describe. You can start here (https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/Mods). Best of luck!

She plays mostly role playing by herself on the iPad, I would like to gets mods for her but I have no idea how to do that or even if you can on the iPad, I'm not the best with technology, if any one knows of a dummie tutorial I can follow on the iPad please let me know. Thanks

Hello xD4DDYx, I have to be honest, there is just no way that features like these will be added unless there is a very good reason to, which there doesn't seem to be. With that in mind, I have two recommendations for you.

1) If your daughter doesn't have a good skin (https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/Skin) already, consider getting her one. There are plenty of skins available that would make your daughter's character look like a young girl, or a cat, or an astronaut, or really whatever she wants to look like. This might help your daughter feel more "in character" when she plays Minecraft.

2) If she is using an iPad, you need to look into add-ons, not mods. Mods are for the computer edition. Read this official article about add-ons (https://minecraft.net/en-us/addons/) to get started. It will take some research to get it to work, and I can't guarantee you'll find exactly what she wants, but you might find something she does like. Hope it works out!

Naturally, children are weaker and slower than adults, so they would have a longer time breaking blocks, slower running, weaker hits, et cetera.

A lot of people are asking to make kid villagers more useful, and this might be our key. I know a lot of little kids and typically they are shy around people who are literally twice their size, but if you were a little kid in Minecraft they would come up to you and trade with you for all sorts of strange items, from the novice level of their trade or just random objects in general.

In superflat worlds there is no way to get to the end unless you turn on those crazy floating strongholds, but now if you can play with the little villagers they might give you something for beating them. Most young kids have a strange and sometimes aggravating habit of picking up the most random objects from gravel to bottle caps to your neighbor’s car keys (LOL). So we can use this trait in the game, if you beat them you have a small percentage of getting a “strange rock” which if enough are collected (144) you could craft the necessary pieces to an END portal. But I wouldn’t enjoy this unless the probability of getting a strange rock or anything useful was below 2-3%. The games could also get harder (in that village only) as you play more because the overall skill is always getting better.

Another fun thing that might be fun is the ability to hide in chests, either just for the pure fun of it or for the ability to hide from monsters.

Another possibility instead of completely changing the gameplay dynamics by being able to spawn as something a block tall, it could be an endgame ability. Like either a special structure that when you jump into its water you shrink and become young “again”.

Or a youthful potion that when you drink it, it makes you young for two hours (so six Minecraft days?). You could brew this with something like a ghost tear, soul sand, and maybe a special drop from baby zombies, vexes or witches?
For Bedrock Edition, in Character Creator, you can make yourself look about 1.5 blocks tall.

Just summarising the comments I've liked the most and adding a few tweaks of my own:
- 'Falcon's Grace' enchantment - honestly while I get the name is like Dolphin's Grace, my OCD doesn't like that it's an enchantment rather than an effect, so a few other name ideas I had were: 'Gravity', 'Mercury', 'Skydancer'.
- Only one level.
- Is like Infinity for elytra and rockets, you need to hold one rocket to boost, and it isn't used up.
- Found in end ships with a low chance.
- Mutually exclusive to the mending enchantment (like Infinity, to balance it).
- Has a cooldown of 5 seconds so you can't just spam boost. During the cooldown you can't use a rocket. 

As people said, late game when you have multiple farms for sugar cane and gunpower, then it's not hard to make rockets - but the same could be said for arrows and the infinity enchantment. If you stop players from putting mending and this enchantment both on the same elytra, then it creates a nice trade-off (which Mojang seem to like doing). You'll likely still get some people who don't mind using rockets, since it makes it easier for elytra to be fixed.

I found a solution to a comment in the post: https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360041247791/comments/4418305572493
You can use a tool called NBTStudio, which you can use to edit world data. If you set hasBeenLoadedInCreative and Cheats tags to 0, you should be able to earn achievements again. Please note that the tool is not supported by Mojang or Microsoft.

Here's what I propose: a medium-sized ship, about 3-4 times the size of a normal boat, with the ability to hold up to 4 passengers and can fit at least 1 or 2 chests. Crafting recipe is simple: have 2 normal boats of the same wood (one in the center slot and one to the left of it), 3 planks of the same wood on the bottom row, and 2 wool at the top-right and center right-hand slots. The ship will be 25% slower a normal boat, but it's balanced out with the extra storage and passenger space. Model doesn't change much: remove the oars, make it bigger, and add a mast with a square(or triangle) sail. Inventory UI would be similar to a donkey/mule's UI when opening up it's inventory. Controls stay the same. Adding chests would have the model of the chests at the rear. Adding a banner would add the design to the sail, or maybe just stick the banner at the top of the mast.

Now, you could do a LOT with this addition: have pillagers spawn in these ships and sail in on you or an unsuspecting village, spawn the wandering trader in one of these and can trade with you out at sea, generate villages out at sea that can have these ships sitting in a dock of some sort. The list goes on and on.

However late I may be to this post, I have done loads of testing and found crossbows super useful, not perfect, but very useful.

Why? Well for starters Both piercing and Multishot allow you to hit multiple mobs without using up an arrow, though if you want easy recovery the crossbow becomes a better closer range weapon. The hit-box on piercing arrows is super lenient, so you don’t need the mobs to be perfectly in a row, in-fact piercing is so good that Multishot is actually nearly useless in comparison. As well, with how the crossbow functions, with a little learning and the quick charge enchantment, it’s actually a vast amount faster than fully charging a bow, even if the single target damage is lower.

Why the speed is key: Quick charge brings the loading time to less than that of the bow, however they difference is that you don’t fire upon release. you actually can load by holding to fire, and once the shot is fired you immediately start reloading, bringing down the reaction time you get from firing consecutive shots with a bow. As well, with a loaded crossbow you always get the fire shot, so by the time a player can aim and fully charge a bow you can have 2 shots fired already, and start loading the third.

They're pretty useful already. You can make multiple, and then just charge all of them. Going into bossfights you can actually just fill up your hotbar with them, and unleash a quick volley for massive dps. This makes certain fights far easier. For just regular mob killing the bow is far better. Mainly because you can one tap just about any basic mob with a single arrow and power V. Unfortunately the amount of situations where you need to kill multiple mobs is quite limited.

I think multishot could be improved. Multiple stages allowing for more arrows. (less damage per individual arrow as a tradeof, and more reload time to make it hard to refresh) And for there to be a shotgun factor where you deal more damage if all shots hit the same target. It certainly allows you to specialise in close quarters combat without damaging sword or others. (At least not any more than how a bow often outshines a enchanted diamond sword up close with enough power...)

I think this would be a nice addition. Balancing this effect with a specific type of armor/enchantment would offset the frustration of a constant speed debuff while in a snow biome.

  • Hooved animals could be immune to this effect. Would incentivize taming mounts.
  • Snow shoes could be added. They might severely reduce the speed debuff or negate it entirely. I'm typically against items with very specific use-cases, but this would be a very minimal addition similar to the turtle shell.
  • In Bedrock, snow piles up after every storm. At 1 layer, this effect could be minimal or absent and increase with every layer after. Replicating the pile effect across all versions would be very welcome, especially if it came with gameplay changes. If this change did come to fruition, snow would have to dissipate over time so snowy biomes don't become completely ruined after a couple storms.
  • This change could be a small addition to a larger update. As of now, snowy biomes have very little to warrant a fundamental change in traversal. Players need a reason to brave the cold, or else they'll avoid the biome entirely.
  • An enchantment negating the effect entirely would be nice, though I'd hate wasting levels and diamonds on making a new pair of boots specifically to get through snow easier.
  • What effect would this have on existing minigames?
  • Having players shovel snow off their walkways or build with snowfall in mind would be a very creative approach at emergent gameplay.

(PS: why don't leaves turn white while it's snowing in Java, huh, Mojang?)

"When broken each Minecart variant drops itself as item, instead of splitting into two items (such as Chest and Minecart)" this is... not great.

I can see how such a change might be useful for folks because it spares you having to reassamble the minecart with [item] every time you break them but the awful downside is this change is PERMANENT. It saves you a whole click of a button, but now functionailty is limited. If you make a minecart with TNT, you are now stuck with it forever. If say you needed a bunch of new Minecarts with Furnaces for a project, rather than repurposing some other minecarts temporarily you are now faced with permanently being stuck with a lot of Minecarts w Furnaces that you can't use for anything else! This creates extra demand for iron as you'll now need to make more minecarts (and find somewhere to store them) for various things rather than repurposing existing ones in a pool if that's all you need. I suppose you could use a Minecart w Furnace as a regular stationary furnace, but now you've gotta fork out iron for rails, too. You also can't use a sign on a Minecart with Chest, so labelling will get tricky for those.

Perhaps a variant such as a "sticky minecart" made with slime that would permanently bind the two together and allow them to be both placed and dropped as one item, vs the regular which would dissassemble on breaking.

Otherwise I've been enjoying the new biome blending and mangrove swamps. Can't wait to assemble a horde of frogs :)

Forget 1.8-reversion toggles or gamerules. I like this idea much more. I assume that, under your ideas, the cooldown mechanism currently shown in the crosshair would be removed in favor of the stamina bar? Thank you for your vote. I absolutely hate this age old discussion and the lie that gamerules will solve everything. I hope both sides will accept this change. 

About your questions, yes, this is a replacement for the current cooldown mechanism, though cooldown will still exist, since you might want to keep your stamina filled. The weakness-like effect caused from stamina depletion will disable the ability to deal damage. You won't be able to swing your weapon at all.

Of course! So it's not so much that cooldown would be removed and more that the nature of the cooldown would change. Instead of being the time period you have to wait between each swing, it would now be the time period you have to wait before swinging once stamina runs out. Got it. I truly hope your idea gets more attention here :)

@Sky2Tate I think he doesn't mean to use the already existing attack speed for this, but is just using it as demonstration to how the math would work out here. It would obviously require all weapons to have a stamina-cost-value instead of the attack speed. 

And I do agree that 6 seconds (3,5 seconds to recover from the 'exhaustion') is far too much, but it does not mean that you can't attack for 6 seconds, but rather something like 3,5 - 4 seconds (longer waiting for heavier weapons like axes).

Best would be that the stamina bar flashes red for 1 or 2 seconds but still fills up like normal (so you can swing your attack like normal afterwards but you can't spam click when the 'exhaustion' is happening)

A sound effect could be played during exhaustion to make it more obvious to the player what is going on (panting or something like that).

@FreakingChicken You could also make weapons with attributes so they have a stamina-cost of 0 so you can spam attack with those still.

Which would also be useful for mapmakers.
Interesting, but it would take away the advantage of landing a preemptive strike, because the attacker would have to wait in combat for his points to fill up again.

And maybe explore the idea of a fixed, but very short delay for attacks? Like, you hit with the sword, and it has a 0.15 second cooldown before you can use it again at all (slower for other weapons), and being exhausted would significantly increase the cooldown, like to 0.3 seconds or 0.4.

This is great! I love the mathematical approach you put into it. But I would say it also might be a good idea to add a potion effect that increases the amount of stamina you have. Also, are you pushing for a combined walking and combat stamina? Or are they two separate spectrums?

Interesting idea, and it would be fun to try, but I would like to warn about adding too much nerdy complexity to the game at the same. I was on the alpha testing team for Carbon's Airmech (an action RTS). In those days, the game was a much more faithful remake of Herzog Zwei, albeit with an updated twist. It was devilishly fun and addictive. But then they kept tweaking it with all these ideas—different power and health levels, time rules, constant re-balancing, etc. It became so arcane and overly complex that you needed a PhD to figure it out as a newcomer. It still enjoys a following on Steam, but it's not what it used to be.

We have to remember that the point of playing a game is, ultimately, for fun. Thus far, Minecraft has remained faithful to that rule. Create too many restrictive rules that require a difficult learning curve or just makes things miserable, and you'll alienate new and old players alike.

This feature has multiple exploits, two mentioned already in comments; it provides easily accessed and endless fuel, and can be abused to destroy builds. Each exploit could be remedied depending on how this feature is implemented.

The first exploit is its ease of use as a fuel source. The obvious solution is to complicate or debuff lava's use as fuel; make it unusable or dangerous. Lava may be too hot for a furnace to contain, the player may lose the bucket containing the iron when its used as fuel, it may destroy items being smelted. The first of these ideas may provide opportunity for a netherite furnace enhancement for endgame players, though this is off-topic.

The second exploit is its use in destruction, to cover large areas in lava with minimal effort. This may be countered by limiting generation of these lava sources. Already are suggestions of limiting source generation to the Nether, although this may be taken further to prevent griefing of nether builds. My proposed solution to this is to limit lava generation to the Nether's ocean level, allowing players to use the lava lakes as a renewable source of lava, but without allowing creation of lava sources above builds.

These suggestions are of course complicated, and it's likely better fitting solutions exist. These exploits may even be welcomed by the community, not needing solutions to begin with. Renewable lava, especially in the Nether, is very fitting to the game and I hope it is implemented.

I just passed sometime in creative exploring caves under y -40 and making a branch mining at y -54, this is my experience:
It's way easier to find diamond at caves, before you would find only 1 block veins very spreadly, but now you can find a lot of blobs more frequently (maybe reduced air exposured is removed?), they are still small blobs (1-3 diamonds), but the fact they are more frequent makes caving actually a good option to find diamonds now (which is cool because it was the fun way but you wouldn't get so much diamonds anymore since 1.18)
Branch mining (with a long 2x2 corridor with 1x2 tunnels along it with 3 blocks between them) doesn't feel that different The veins size used to always be 8 diamonds when mining, but now it seems to have more variation in size going 3-6 diamonds most of times (it's still bigger than the air exposured ones in the caves), so with the bigger frequency makes the amount of diamonds per time mined still the same, and also makes the branch mining less tedious and more exciting, it's more fun to find 3 blobs of 4 in ten minutes, than just 1 of 8 in 10 minutes

Overall these changes makes caving a good option to mine diamonds without making branch mining less efficient as well (because mining deepslate takes way to much time), combining both makes mining diamonds overall less grindy and time comsuming to get a good amount in a area. Before it would need always go branch mining and go for LONG (slow mining) tunnels to be efficient

I feel like this change is not addressing Minecraft's balance issue, which leads to the game feeling less satisfying than it should be. I think the distribution of diamonds and diamond ore across the game needs to be looked at to help make the mining experience satisfying for the player. Additionally, diamonds feel useless after a certain point. I believe the two major issues causing this problem are: A) diamonds and diamond gear being too easily accessible via other methods and B) diamonds not scaling with difficulty. 

Firstly I think that one of the primary issues with Minecraft's diamond distribution is that diamonds and diamond gear can be obtained too easily. The player can get diamonds through too many ways, like shipwrecks, villager trades, and the newly added archeology system. But I feel like this accessibility diminishes the significance of actually finding diamond ore through mining. It makes the game less rewarding in the long run because the player has too many easily obtained diamonds. Additionally, handing out diamond tools further diminishes that sense of accomplishment.

Secondly, diamonds should be used as a reward for facing a challenge. Increasing the diamonds on lower levels is a small step towards fixing this problem, but now they are too common there too. I think the biome should play a role in diamond placement. But in order to keep balance, diamonds and diamond ore should be significantly reduced elsewhere.
